The following table is a comparison of the colourblind 
equations deduced from Mr Simpsons observations alone 
with those deduced from my observations and the value 
of D. 

Table C 
V U G B W Y 
[text?]/J.S. +96 +4 -24 -76 0 0 
[text?]D +93.9 +6.1 -21.7 -78.3 0 0 
[text?]/J.S -70 +27 +73 0 -30 0 
M&D -70 +27.2 -72.8 0 -30 0 
[text?]/J.S -19 +40 -81 0 0 +60 
M&D -13.6 +38.5 -86.4 0 0 +61.5 
The average error here is 1.9, smaller than the average error 
of the individual colour=blind observations, showing that 
the theory of colour=blindness being the <s>result of<\s> want 
of a cer- tain colour=sensation which is one of the three 
ordinary colour sensations, agrees with observation to 
within the limits of error. 

In fig(4) I have laid down the chromatic relations 
of these colours accord- ing to Newtons method. 
V, (vermillion) U (Ultramarine) and G (Emerald Green) are assumed 
as standard colours, and placed at the angles of an equilateral 
triangle. The position of W (white) and Y (Pale Chrome Yellow) 
with respect to these are laid down from equations 7 & 8, deduced from
